articles.description:
There are unemployment problems and recruitment problems in English general practice. The RCGP has written to the commissioner asking for a guarantee that the Targeted Enhanced Recruitment Scheme (TERS) will continue to be funded for 2025/26 and beyond. The national incentive programme funds £20,000 salary supplements to
The post ‘Golden handshake’ GP recruitment scheme ‘under threat’, RCGP warns appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post Physician associates have ‘no role’ in general practice, RCGP tells Leng review appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post NHS England expands mpox vaccination for high-risk groups appeared first on Pulse Today.

But there is little
The post NHS England planning guidance ‘fails to see’ vital role of GPs, leaders warn appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post Embattled GP company hands back contract following staff pay concerns appeared first on Pulse Today.

Looking at the Clinical Practice Research Datalink, which
The post GP continuity reduces workload in practices and A&E, study suggests appeared first on Pulse Today.

The post Quarter of GP practices have had to shrink team size due to financial squeeze appeared first on Pulse Today.

An analysis of the National Child Mortality Database found in 2022/23, there were 258 more child deaths than expected when compared with figures from the pre-pandemic period. During national lockdowns – April 2020 to March

The post Dapagliflozin in addition to calorie restriction boosts diabetes remission chances appeared first on Pulse Today.

articles.description: The 2025/26 financial year is a 'reset moment' for the NHS, according to an updated strategic plan that puts plans to improve GP access among national priorities for the year ahead.

articles.description: Now in its sixth year, MIMS Learning Live Digital will take place over 4 evenings from 10-13 March 2025.
articles.title: Focus on CPD learning at a unique digital event

articles.description: NHS officials have told MPs they cannot say what proportion of health service funding will shift to community services as part of government plans to move care out of hospitals.
articles.title: MPs 'exasperated' as officials unable to commit on NHS community funding shift

articles.description: Just over a quarter of GP practices have stopped providing non-NHS services in the past 12 months because of rising workload, a survey suggests.
articles.title: Swamped GP practices forced to cut private services that help boost income

articles.description: UK health officials have expanded the range of antibiotics recommended as first- or second-choice options for most common infections in an overhaul of advice designed to improve antibiotic stewardship and reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance.
articles.title: First-choice antibiotic options widened in overhaul by UK health officials

articles.description: LMCs could call for a move towards full industrial action, a threat of mass resignation or stopping all non-core work at a March conference to debate potential escalation from current collective action by GP practices.
articles.title: Special conference could push for industrial action or mass resignation threat

articles.description: It would never be appropriate for a doctor to recommend assisted dying - but legislation should allow them to raise the issue with patients if it is legalised, a leading GP has told MPs.
articles.title: No doctor should ever recommend assisted dying, says BMA ethics chair

articles.description: Key government aims for the NHS - including plans to shift care from hospitals to the community - could be at risk because 'complacent' NHS and DHSC officials may not be ready to drive them through, MPs have warned in a report that also calls for a review of GP vaccination payments.
articles.title: 'Complacent' health officials lack ideas to save NHS, MPs warn

articles.description: Key government aims for the NHS - including plans to shift care from hospitals to the community - could be at risk because 'complacent' NHS and DHSC officials may not be ready to drive them through, MPs have warned in a report that also calls for a review of GP vaccination payments.
articles.title: 'Complacent' NHS officials lack ideas to save NHS, MPs warn

articles.description: International medical graduate (IMG) GPs are at risk of being ‘exploited for cheap labour’ under the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), the BMA GP registrar committee has warned.
articles.title: IMG GPs risk being ‘exploited for cheap labour’ through ARRS

articles.description: GP contract negotiations for 2025/26 are expected to conclude in February - well ahead of a special LMCs conference in March that will debate whether to step up industrial action, GP leaders have said.
articles.title: GP contract talks for 2025/26 to finish in February

articles.description: One in 10 appointments in general practice could be avoided if patients always saw a regular GP, according to research that suggests continuity of care could dramatically reduce practice workload.
articles.title: GP continuity delivers dramatic reduction in appointments, study suggests

articles.description: GPs should consider asking patients about gambling during health checks and appointments, particularly during conversations about behaviours that can point to increased risk, the first-ever NICE guideline on the topic advises.

articles.description: General practice in Scotland will receive a £10.5m investment to boost capacity and improve prevention - along with a rising share of future NHS funding, the country’s first minister has revealed.

articles.description: GP services in parts of the UK have been hit hard by Storm Éowyn, as two practices in Scotland saw their roofs torn off while in other parts of the country practices closed, lost power, or switched to emergency appointments only.

articles.description: There is 'no chance' the government will meet its goal of recruiting more than 1,000 GPs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) by the end of March, GP leaders have warned.

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses the key news stories affecting general practice.

articles.description: NHS health checks should be commissioned as a directed enhanced services to end 'mind-boggling' variation in how they work across the country, the BMA England GP committee deputy chair has told MPs.

articles.description: The overall GP workforce grew by 2.6% in 2024 - the second successive year in which GP numbers have risen - but doctors' leaders have warned that the accelerating decline of partners leaves the profession's future at risk.

articles.description: Take part in our survey, which also asks about key issues affecting locum GPsm and you could be in with a chance of winning £250 of John Lewis vouchers.

articles.description: A GP suspended from the medical register following a conviction for taking part in a climate change protest has had an appeal against the decision rejected by the High Court.

articles.description: GP practices are continuing to step up collective action at the start of 2025 despite appeals from the government for the profession to back down.

articles.description:
WHO and partners have immediately boosted their support to the Ugandan government’s response to an outbreak of Sudan virus disease outbreak (SVD, part of the Ebola family), including by facilitating access to a candidate vaccine and candidate treatments. The first 2160 doses of the vaccine candidate and the treatments are already in Kampala, Uganda, as they were prepositioned as part of outbreak preparedness.  
The vaccine trial processes underway include orientation of the research teams on the trial procedures, and logistics arrangements. Research teams have been deployed to the field to work along with the surveillance teams as approvals are awaited.
The candidate vaccine and the candidate treatments (a monoclonal antibody and an antiviral) are being made available through clinical tria…
articles.title: WHO and partners enable access to candidate vaccine and treatments for outbreak of Sudan Ebola virus disease in Uganda

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) expresses deep concern about the implications of the immediate funding pause for HIV programmes in low- and middle-income countries. These programmes provide access to life-saving HIV therapy to more than 30 million people worldwide. Globally, 39.9 million people were living with HIV at the end of 2023. 
A funding halt for HIV programmes can put people living with HIV at immediate increased risk of illness and death and undermine efforts to prevent transmission in communities and countries. Such measures, if prolonged, could lead to rises in new infections and deaths, reversing decades of progress and potentially taking the world back to the 1980s and 1990s when millions died of HIV every year globally, including many in the United States of America. 
Fo…
articles.title: WHO statement on potential global threat to people living with HIV

articles.description:
Following a nearly century-long effort, Georgia has been certified malaria-free by the World Health Organization (WHO). With today’s announcement, Georgia joins the ranks of 45 countries and 1 territory that have achieved this milestone.
“Today we congratulate the people of Georgia for their decades of targeted and sustained actions to eliminate malaria, one of the world’s leading killers,” said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General. “Georgia’s commitment and success gives us hope that a malaria-free world is possible.”
“This is a huge milestone worth marking; with Georgia’s achievement, the WHO European Region is another step closer to initiate certification as the first malaria-free region in the world,” said Dr Hans Henri P. Kluge, WHO Regional Director for Europe. “This d…
articles.title: Georgia certified malaria-free by WHO

articles.description: The World Health Organization regrets the announcement that the United States of America intends to withdraw from the organization.
articles.title: WHO comments on United States’ announcement of intent to withdraw

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) welcomes the Gaza ceasefire, hostage and prisoner release deal, which brings hope for millions of people whose lives have been ravaged by the conflict.   
The health challenges ahead are immense. The entire population of Gaza has faced multiple displacements. More than 46 600 people have been killed and over 110 000 have been injured. The real figures are likely much higher. Only half of Gaza’s 36 hospitals remain partially operational, nearly all hospitals are damaged or partly destroyed, and just 38% of primary health care centres are functional. An estimated 25% of those injured – around 30 000 people – face life-changing injuries and will need ongoing rehabilitation. Specialized health care is largely unavailable, medical evacuations abroad are extre…
articles.title: The ceasefire in Gaza brings hope, but immense challenges lie ahead to restore the health system

articles.description:
Conflict, climate change, epidemics, and displacement are converging to create an unparalleled global health crisis, with 305 million people in urgent need of humanitarian assistance in 2025. In response, the World Health Organization (WHO) is calling for US$ 1.5 billion for its 2025 Health Emergency Appeal (HEA), to support life-saving health interventions worldwide.
The appeal, launched today by WHO Director-General, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, outlines the critical priorities and resources needed to address 42 ongoing health emergencies, including 17 Grade 3 crises – the most severe emergencies requiring the highest level of response. With health systems stretched to their limits and global financial resources dwindling, the US$ 1.5 billion are needed to help people facing the most d…
articles.title: WHO launches US$ 1.5 billion Health Emergency Appeal to tackle unprecedented global health crises

articles.description:
On 18 December 2024, the World Health Organization (WHO) prequalified the first diagnostic test for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency which can help to safely deliver WHO-recommended treatments to prevent relapse of Plasmodium vivax (P. vivax) infection.
The prequalification of this G6PD diagnostic test marks a significant milestone in facilitating safe and effective P. vivax malaria treatment, reaffirming WHO’s dedication to ensuring equitable access to life-saving health solutions globally. Some 500 000 people die each year from malaria, most of them children.
The prequalification of this test immediately followed the prequalification, in early December, of two new tafenoquine products for anti-relapse treatment of P. vivax malaria, and these therapeutics were recommend…
articles.title: WHO prequalifies diagnostic test to support safer administration of P. vivax malaria treatments

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: NHS Shared Business Services (NHS SBS) is planning the formation of a new framework agreement for AI solutions in healthcare.

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Care Quality Commission (CQC) revealed that it has around 500 reports which are “stuck” in its IT platform and cannot be retrieved.

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: Robeauté has raised $28m (£23m) to develop its microrobots which enter the brain to diagnose, treat and monitor neurological conditions.

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Royal Bolton Hospital is carrying out digital autopsies that reduce invasive post-mortems and release bodies back to families sooner.
articles.title: Royal Bolton Hospital opens digital autopsy suite

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: UK health tech firm Cera has completed a transaction in excess of $150m (£123m) to further scale its AI-led home healthcare technology.

articles.author: Tammy Lovell
articles.description: This episode of Digital Health Unplugged features Holly Coole from the MHRA discussing the regulation of digital mental health technologies.

articles.description: Our latest news roundup covers cleaning robots at South Tees Hospitals and a £10 million framework for data validation services.

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Prime minister Keir Starmer has unveiled details of the government’s AI Opportunities Action Plan, which includes a National Data Library.

articles.author: DHI News Team
articles.description: Microsoft has been confirmed as the co-headline sponsor of Digital Health Rewired 2025, the UK’s biggest and best digital health conference.

articles.description: A CBT-based mobile game designed to help children self-manage anxiety is now available across Herefordshire and Worcestershire.

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The Crown Commercial Service has included twice the number of suppliers in the latest version of its Digital Capability for Health framework.

articles.description: Releaf has launched a £2 million proprietary tech platform to transform how patients access medical cannabis treatment.

articles.description: PocDoc has partnered with the West Yorkshire Health and Care Partnership to roll out cardiovascular disease (CVD) health screenings.

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: The latest contracts features two Essex trusts announcing plans to deliver an Oracle Health electronic patient record (EPR).

articles.author: Owen Hughes
articles.description: The highly anticipated programme for Digital Health Rewired 2025, which takes place at NEC Birmingham on 18-19 March, has been published.

articles.description: Today's news roundup covers funding for an integrated housing and care technology project and research into using AI to help IVF success.
articles.title: Digital Health Coffee Time Briefing ☕

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: Pathology software and services company Deciphex has closed its Series C financing, raising $32.3m to expand access to high-quality pathology.

articles.description: Airedale and Bradford hospitals have teamed together to create and launch a digital resource for patients on diagnosing Lynch Syndrome.

articles.description: Researchers at The Clatterbridge Cancer Centre NHS Foundation Trust are using AI to enhance the precision of radiotherapy for prostate cancer.

articles.description: Sheffield Children’s has rolled out System C's electronic prescribing and medicine administration system in its Paediatric Critical Care Unit.

articles.description: A trial of an AI tool, conducted by Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, is identifying people at risk of developing atrial fibrillation.

articles.description: Our latest Coffee Time Briefing covers a new online prescription service at Morrisons and a CBE for Milton Keynes CEO, Joe Harrison.

articles.author: Jordan Sollof
articles.description: An electronic health record and app will be rolled out across Wales to enable mothers-to-be to access their full maternity records instantly.

articles.description: John Quinn, chief information officer (CIO) at NHS England, has announced he will leave the role at the end of March 2024.

articles.description: The government is upgrading the NHS App to enable patients to choose providers, book appointments and receive test results, all in one place.
